column2: Description
column5: Water

column2: Aconite flowers are also known as winter aconite. They spread easily and can be planted as tubers or seeds. Aconite is often found growing in patches and is spring’s first flower.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: Ageratum is a tough plant that is a favorite for many gardens. These beautiful blue annuals are known for their powder puff blooms.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to mid-fall.

column2: Allium is also known as flowering onion. This plant grows from a bulb or from seed and produces globes of purple clusters of flowers atop long stems.
column5: Blooms in late spring to mid-summer

column2: Alstroemeria is a flower commonly used in floral arrangements due to its variation in colors and its ability to be dyed. Their blooms make it easy for florists to create bouquets such as “100 blooms.”
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early spring to late summer.

column2: Amaryllis flowers are one of the easiest to grow. They do very well indoors or out and come in a variety of colors. Try to plant the largest bulbs you can find because larger bulbs mean more flowers!
column5: Blooms in early spring to mid-summer.

column2: Anemone is also known as windflower. These tuberous flowers produce poppy-like blooms in early-to-mid spring and come in a variety of colors ranging from white to red and purple. Anemone is a buttercup.
column3: Plant in full sun or part shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring to mid-fall.

column2: Angelica is a tall hardy biennial herb with stalks that can be candied and used on cakes or cookies. It produces green foliage in the first year and flowers in the second.
column3: Plant in partial shade or full shade.
column4: It needs well-drained high fertility soil.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Angelonia is also known as summer snapdragon. It is a fairly new plant that has only been around since the late 1990s. Angelonia is a tough perennial and stands up to heat with no problem.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to mid-fall.

column2: Artemisia is a perennial plant that is grown more for its silvery white foliage than for the small white flowers; it makes an excellent backdrop for more showy flowers in a perennial bed.
column5: Blooms in late summer.

column2: Aster blooms in late summer to early fall when many other perennials have faded. They range from varieties that skim the ground to those towering 6 feet high. The daisy-like flowers come in many colors; the most common shades are purple/lavender/pink/red/blue/white.
column4: Plant asters in moist well-drained soil.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early fall.

column2: Astilbe is known for being a graceful flower that does well in cooler climates in the northern third of the country. It can tolerate full sun as long as it has a constant supply of moisture.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column4: It needs well-drained high fertility soil.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early fall.

column2: Aubrieta is named after the French artist who made them famous from his paintings. They are perfect for rock gardens.
column4: It needs well-drained high fertility soil.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring to early summer.

column2: Alyssum is classified as a perennial plant grown as an annual in cold climates. Its tiny clusters of blooms are attractive at the edge of a bed or in pots with geraniums or other annuals.
column5: Blooms spring through fall.

column2: Azaleas are a type of rhododendrons. They come in a range of colors and beautiful shades. These shrubs can make a beautiful addition to your garden.
column4: It needs well-drained high fertility soil.
column5: Bloom in the spring

column2: Balloon flowers are known for being great cut flowers and for having petals that can be popped. The Foliage turns clear gold in the fall.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Balsam Is an old-fashioned annual that was a favorite of Victorian gardens. These impatiens are also known as the touch-me-not flower.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: Baneberry is a white fluffy flower that produces ornamental and poisonous red berries. It’s perfect for cool areas.
column3: Plant in partial shade or full shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring.

column2: Basket of Gold flowers grows in large bunches that resemble baskets of gold. They are perfect for rock gardens due to their short height.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Bee balm flowers are also known as monarda/bergamot/Oswego tea. These flowers are perfect for attracting bees. Their blossoms resemble fireworks and come in many colors.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: Begonia is an easy-to-grow flower that does great in many different conditions. They come in many different visual varieties. It’s a perennial plant.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early fall.

column2: Bellflowers are known for their resemblance to bells and are also called Campanula. These flowers come in many sizes and varieties.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Bergenia is also known as pigsqueak due to the sound their leaves make when rubbed together. The flower blooms in a beautiful array of pinks and whites and is native to central Asia.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade
column5: Blooms in spring.

column2: Blackeyed Susan is a member of the sunflower family known for attracting butterflies and bees. It grows in gardens and is also found in meadows and is a hardy plant.
column5: Blooms in late summer to mid-fall.

column2: Bleeding-heart flowers are a favorite for many gardens due to their heart-shaped pink or white flowers. They are part of the poppy family.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Bloodroot is named for its red-colored sap that flows from the stem when cut. It was originally used as war paint by Native Americans and is also known for its medicinal qualities.
column3: Plant in partial or full shade.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: Boneset is a wildflower that is very easy to grow and can spread quickly. It’s great for natural-looking gardens. Boneset is a perennial plant and is also known as eupatorium perfoliatum.
column3: Plant in full sun to partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late summer to mid-fall.

column2: Browallias are a bright purple and blue flowers that are great in containers or planted in a row as a border. It is commonly known as bush violet and is a perennial. The flower is named for Swedish botanist Johan Browall.
column3: Plant in partial shade or full shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: Bugleweed (also known as Ajuga) is a great choice to fill in gardens and can easily spread. Only varieties with purple leaves do well in the heat. Bugleweed is often used as a supplement to treat a variety of ailments.
column3: Plant in partial shade or full shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Bugloss is a hard to find flower that can be short-lived but easily produces seeds. Siberian bugloss is also known as Brunnera.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Buttercup flowers are a plant that is fun and cheerful - common in grassland and as a garden weed. They are also known as Ranunculus bulbosus. Buttercups are occasionally used as a supplement.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Butterfly Weed is also known as Pleurisy Root. This plant produces warm color blooms and can do very well in poor quality soil. It is a species of milkweed.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Caladium is a tropical plant with clumping heart-shaped leaves that are available in a variety of colors. They are also known as Heart of Jesus - as well as Elephant Ear and Angel Wings.
column3: Plant in partial or full shade.
column5: Blooms in early spring to mid-fall.

column2: Calendula is grown mainly for cut flowers but it can also be used as an herb. They come in a variety of yellow and orange colors. It is also known as pot marigold and often sold as a cream or in oil form.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to mid-fall.

column2: The California Poppy is a wildflower native to both the United States and Mexico. These flowers can add a pop of color to dry hot areas. They are used as a supplement to treat a variety of sleep-related issues such as insomnia.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: Calla lilies are hardy plants that grow in full sun or partial shade. They’re available in various colors with classic white making an elegant gift or addition to your home.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms midsummer to early fall

column2: Canna are tall blooms grow on spike-like stalks that are sure to draw attention. When grown in the correct environment they are very easy to care for.
column5: Blooms in early summer.

column2: Canterbury Bells is an older flower known for its beautiful colors - a very common flower found in England. It is an annual or biennial flower and feature bell-shaped blooms in colors ranging from pink to purple and white.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to mid-summer.

column2: Cardinal Flower is known for its vivid scarlet red blooms. This flower can grow as high as 4 feet and attracts beneficial insects. It is part of the Bellflower family.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Carnation (also known as Dianthus caryophyllus) is a very popular flower for both gardens and bouquets. Each color represents a symbol of love or friendship. Each color has its own meaning similar to roses.
column5: Blooms in early spring to late summer.

column2: Castor Bean is a great plant for backdrops in a garden - it has large leaves and can grow up to 10 feet tall. It is also known as Ricinus communis and is used to create a toxic and illegal substance: ricin.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: The catmint plant is easy to take care of/tolerates dry climates/and is loved by cats. It is an herb that yields bluish-purple flowers.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Celosia (also known as Cocks Comb) is a fascinating unique looking flower that blooms in a variety of warm colors. They are an annual flower.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to mid-fall.

column2: Chives are known for being a popular herb - the flowers it produces are a beautiful purple that can be perfect for edging in flower gardens. This is a close relative of green onions/shallots/leeks.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early fall.

column2: Chrysanthemum is perfect for fall gardens as they produce fantastic flowers with lots of colors later in the season than most others. They are often called Mums and are a popular flower for Mother’s Day.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late fall.

column2: Clary Sage is the perfect flower to grow in containers if you don’t have space for a garden. These flowers are often used as decorations in the home or dried.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to mid-fall.

column2: Cleome (also known as the spider flower) is very easy to grow but can quickly spread and take over a garden as they self-seed. They are annual flowers and are fairly easy to grow.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Cockscomb plants are known for their odd bloom formation - which resembles a brain. These flowers will certainly be a conversation starter.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: Coleus Plants are a leafy or succulent plant that comes in many species. They can produce a wide array of colors. Even though they are perennials they typically show up as annuals because of their sensitivity to cold climates.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: Columbine flowers are short-lived; when they bloom they are a stunning addition to any garden. They come in call colors of the rainbow and is the official state flower of Colorado.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring to early summer.

column2: Comfrey produces a variety of blue and purple flowers. The leaves from this plant are also loaded with nutrients that make a great addition to fertilizer or compost.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: The Coneflower is Native to America and produces a variety of colors that are perfect for attracting butterflies and honey bees.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Coreopsis is a bright long-lasting flower that attracts both birds and butterflies. It is commonly known as tickseed and is an easy-to-care-for perennial.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late summer to mid-fall.

column2: Corydalis is a bright flower that is long-lasting and perfect for shady areas. It is also used as a medicinal supplement - primarily in extract or powder form - to address depression and act as a sedative.
column3: Plant in partial shade or full shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer or early fall.

column2: The cosmos flower grows in a variety of pinks that will last all season and is part of the sunflower family. The unique foliage makes a great backdrop for other shorter plants.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to mid-fall.

column2: Crocus flowers are one of the earliest growing plants of spring. They deal well with cool weather as long as they get the proper amount of sunlight and are a perennial.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: The Crown Imperial is a unique plant grows all of its flowers on one long stem. It produces warm color blooms and is also known as Fritillaria imperialis.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring.

column2: Cushion Spurge is perfect for dry climates with interesting foliage that can be red/purple/green. It’s also known as Euphorbia epithymoides.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring to late summer.

column2: Cyclamen is popular due to its heart-shaped petals. This flower is also a perfect food source for both insects and animal. It is a perennial.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: Daffodils are a well-known flower that is often representative of spring. These are some of our favorite flowers to see in the gardens every year. Daffodils come in many colors with one to 5 flowers per stem.
column5: Blooms in spring.

column2: Dahlia is a popular tubular flower that has 42 different species and grows in a variety of bright colors. It’s native to Central America and Mexico and grows from small tubers.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: The daisy is an easy to grow flower that is instantly recognizable. Brightly-colored Gerbera daisies are our absolute favorites but there are numerous other types of daisies.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Dame’s Rocket is found in white and violet - this flower is easy to grow and can spread quickly in the right conditions. It is both fragrant and edible. It’s also extremely invasive.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Delphinium is also known as Larkspur. They appear in long stalks of pink/blue/white/purple and are perennial.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Dianthus are uniquely scented with pink/purple/ white blooms. This flower is easy to grow and is often found in wedding bouquets. It’s also known as a Pink flower.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to late summer.

column2: The Diascia plant produces a delicate pink flower that has become popular because it can be planted so early in the spring. It’s also known as Twinspur.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: The Dusty Miller plant (also known as Silver ragwort) has a silver foliage that resembles lace. It is commonly used for backdrops in gardens containing bright flowers.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late summer to early fall.

column2: Dutchman’s Breeches is recognizable for its up-side-down hanging flowers that look like a pair of pants. They are unique because ants spread their seeds. It flowers in spring and is also known as Dicentra cucullaria.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring.

column2: Epimedium is a short growing flower that produces pink/yellow/purple flowers. It’s known by various different names including barrenwort/bishop’s hat/fairy wings/horny goat weed. This is occasionally used as a supplement since it produces effects similar to testosterone.
column3: Plant in partial shade to full shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring to late spring.

column2: Evergreen Candytuft produces small puff-like blooms and is perfect for planting around rocks due to its cascading effect. It’s considered an evergreen though many gardeners prefer to treat it as a perennial.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring.

column2: Fennel is commonly grown for use in cooking. When grown for aesthetic reasons it can reach up to 6 feet tall and will attract butterflies.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: Fountain Grass is an ornamental grass that comes in a variety of colors. It’s also referred to as crimson fountaingrass.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early fall.

column2: Foxglove flowers can be hard to grow. It takes two years for flowers to bloom but it is worth it to see the beautiful tubular flowers it produces.
column3: Plant in all types of sun.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Gaillardias are bright flowers that are great for hot dry areas. They are a genus of sunflowers and are also known as blanket flowers.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: Gardenias are unofficially known as the flower of the South. These bright white flowers have beautiful contrasting dark leaves. They are part of the coffee family.
column3: Plant in direct sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms late summer to early fall.

column2: The gas plant (also known as Dictamnus) produces pink or white flowers which give off a flammable gas. It is recommended to wear gloves when touching this shrub. Another common name for this flowering plant is burning bush.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Gaura is a delicate perennial flower that resembles butterflies. This flower is perfect for flower beds and is native in both Texas and Louisiana.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Gazanias are rugged plants that can handle extreme heat and drought. Their flowers can grow up to 4 inches across. The flower is also known as the African Daisy and is native to Southern Africa.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Geraniums have been used in gardens for over a century and it’s still a popular plant due to its love of hot weather and multiple colors. This flowering plant is also known as Pelargonium.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Geum is a hard-to-grow flower with blooms that last only a couple of months. The colorful flower makes it worth growing! It’s commonly known as Avens and is part of the rose family.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Globe Thistles have bright blue and violet flowers which attract bees and butterflies. They are perennials and are also known as Echinops bannaticus.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Glory of the Snow have vivid purple and blue blooms and provide perfect ground covering for gardens. Its scientific name is Chionodoxa and it is a perennial.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: Goatsbeard have tall stalks of wispy white flowers that can reach up to 6 feet high. Its scientific name is Aruncus dioicus and is also known as bride’s feathers.
column3: Plant in partial and full shade.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Golden Marguerite is also known as golden or yellow chamomile and cota tinctoria. Its bright yellow blooms grow perfectly when mixed in with other close-growing plants. This is a perennial and looks a bit like a daisy.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Gomphrenas are known for their use in Hawaiian leis. These flowers are strong and easy to grow and are also referred to as globe amaranths. They are an annual flower and often have a bright pink color.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to mid-fall.

column2: Heliconias produce orange and yellow blooms that resemble lobster claws. Ensure you have plenty of room if you plan to grow these as they are known to spread quickly and grow between 4-30 feet. They are beautiful tropical flowers and come in vivid shades.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Heliotropes are a highly scented flower that grows purple/blue/white blooms. These are highly toxic to dogs and cats - be careful if you have pets around. These are symbolic flowers with multiple meanings including eternal love and religious devotion.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Hepatica flowers have blooms that come in shades of blue/pink/violet/white. The leaves of this plant resemble a human liver - which is where it gets its name from. They are actually part of the buttercup family.
column3: Plant in partial shade or full shade.
column5: Blooms in early spring to mid-spring.

column2: Hibiscus blooms are different in that they actually grow on small trees. They tend to be a tropical island flower as they need a very specific climate to thrive.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early spring to late summer.

column2: Hollyhocks can grow up to 3 feet tall with many blooms on each stalk in a popular garden plant. These flowers have the scientific name Alcea and bloom during the summer months. They’re known for making an appearance in the front of cottages andare found in many colors.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Hostas (also known as Plantain lilies) are a commonly grown plant. They’re great to grow because of their love of shade and their visual variety. Hosta plants are hardy perennials.
column3: Plant in partial shade to full shade.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Hyacinths (also known as Hyacinthus) are fragrant flowers with large clusters of flowers in many different colors. They have beautiful blooms and often begin to appear in spring.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Hydrangeas (also known as hortensia) feature clumping blooms that grow together in large bunches. This unique flower can be a challenge to grow - but once it blooms it becomes very easy to maintain.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to late summer.

column2: Hyssops are a long-blooming plant. They can grow up to 8 feet tall and attract hummingbirds and butterflies. Hyssopus Officinalis is a medicinal plant used to treat a number of ailments including digestive issues.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: Impatiens (also known as touch-me-not) are an indoor or outdoor plant with flowers in almost every color of the rainbow. New Guinea Impatiens are very popular and grow in a hot pink color.
column3: Plant in partial shade or full shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Irises grow in a variety of colors that sometimes bloom both at the beginning of spring and then again in late summer. The iris flower is the state flower of Tennessee and the most frequently planted variety in the USA is the bearded iris.
column5: Blooms in early spring to early fall.

column2: Jack-in-the-Pulpit (also known as Arisaema triphyllum) is a unique green flower with a leaflike bloom. It’s a perennial and has also been referred to as an Indian Turnip.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring to late spring.

column2: The Jacob’s Ladder plant has blue/white/purple blooms with leaves that resemble a ladder going up the stem. Its scientific name is polemonium caeruleum and it’s also referred to as Greek valerian. Jacob’s Ladder is hardy - making it a good choice for beginners.
column5: Blooms in late spring to mid-summer.

column2: Lady’s Mantle (or alchemilla mollis) is a medicinal herb that also has beautiful green foliage. It’s a hardy perennial and is known for its anti-inflammatory properties.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Lantana is perfect for hot dry areas. These flowers grow in many warm colors and will attract butterflies and hummingbirds. They are part of the Verbena family and prefer warm temperatures.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: Lavender is easily recognized by its purple blooms and strong scent. The flower is often used as part of aromatherapy for its essential oils and relaxing properties.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Lavender Cotton (Santolina chamaecyparissus) is used in gardens for its contrasting foliage and unique green and silver color. It’s an evergreen shrub which yields yellow blooms.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to late summer.

column2: Leadwort - part of the plumbago family - is a late-blooming flower that will provide bright colors to any garden. It is a perennial that is frequently used for groundcover.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late summer to early fall.

column2: Lemon Balm (also known as balm mint) is a bright green leafy plant that will help keep mosquitoes away. This herb is often used as a tea.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Lilac is also known as Syringa or Syringa vulgaris. People assume that they are always purple - however lilac also blooms in white. They have a beautiful meaning – both early love as well as innocence.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring to late spring.

column2: Lilies are a highly recognized flower that has bright colors and a strong scent. They come in a variety of colors and have trumpet-like blooms.
column5: Blooms in spring to early fall.

column2: The Lily of the Valley (also known as a Victorian flower or Convallaria majalis) is an easy plant to grow. Once it blooms the flowers will only stay alive for about one week. This plant is often used as ground cover and its blooms have a sweet smell.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: Lisianthus flowers (Eustoma grandiflorum) can bloom late into the season if taken care of properly — it is important always to keep them watered well after the first bloom. They are perennial and grow best in warm climates.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Lobelias have interesting blooms with a combination of white/red/violet/blue color and are often found in hanging pots. They are also known for their medicinal qualities and used to treat athsma and other respiratory issues.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: Lupine flowers feature cone-shaped blooms and come in a variety of colors. These wildflowers grow on long stems.
column3: Plant in full sun to partial shade.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Maiden Pink dianthus is used as ground cover. These blooms have a unique pattern in shades of pink and white. They are known to partially close up at dawn.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Malva is part of the classification Malvaceae and is found growing in the wild with purple and pink blooms. One of the most popular types is malva sylvestris - which is also known as the common mallow.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Marigolds have the scientific name tagetes. They are an easy to grow flower both indoors and outside that produces blooms in yellow/orange/white/gold. Marigold flowers are annuals.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: Mazus reptans (also known as creeping mazus) feature delicate purple/blue/white blooms with a single white-spotted petal. It is primarily used for groundcover and is a perennial.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in late spring to early summer.

column2: Mirabilis grow flowers in a variety of colors and last well into fall. The reason they are called four o’clocks is that they tend to open in the afternoon. The wildflower called Mirabilis multiflora is known as the Colorado four o’clock.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to mid-fall.

column2: The moonflower is an interesting flower which only blooms at dusk and will close up at first light. It’s also known as a tropical white morning-glory. Moonflowers are fragrant annuals and are pollinated by insects that fly at night.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Morning glories are the perfect flower to grow near fences as they grow on vine-like stalks. The name morning glory is actually just the common name for flowers in the family Convolvulaceae. They bloom in the summer and are known for their trumpet shape which is typically seen in blue or purple.
column5: Blooms in early summer to early fall.

column2: Nasturtiums are easy to grow flowers that will last all season. They grow in a variety of yellows and oranges. They are annuals and are occasionally used in salads or sauces.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: Nierembergia (cupflower/purple robe) is great as an indoor plant or as edging on the border of a garden. It comes in a variety of colors and is low-growing.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: The orchid is commonly grown as a houseplant due to both its beauty and ease of growth. Orchids can grow to 3 feet tall and make a beautiful gift or addition to your home.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column4: It needs rocks instead of soil.
column5: Blooms in early spring to early fall.

column2: Osteospermum (also known as African daisies) is a cool-season plant that comes in many bright colors. They are part of the daisy family.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to mid-fall.

column2: Pansies are perfect for both outdoor growing and as a household plant. They will usually last until the first few touches of frost when grown outside.
column3: Plant in full sun to partial shade.
column5: Blooms in spring.

column2: The pasque (or pasqueflower) is the official flower of South Dakota. These are hardy plants that do well in cool climates. It’s a perennial flower that blooms in the spring.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in early spring to early fall.

column2: Pearly everlasting flowers are usually grown for the purpose of drying; these tiny white blooms are also beautiful in a garden. Its scientific name is Anaphalis margaritacea and it is part of the sunflower family.
column3: Plant in full sun to partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-summer to early fall.

column2: Pentas flowers come in many different colors and are one of the top types of flowers for attracting butterflies. They are known for their blooms - which only produce four petals - and are part of the Rubiaceae flower.
column5: Blooms in early spring.

column2: Peonies produce large fragrant blooms. After a few years they will develop into large bushes. This type of flower (also known as paeony) come in white/pink/purple and is very fragrant.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.
column5: Blooms in mid-spring.

column2: Perennial Flax (also known as Linum perenne) is a hard to grow bloom that does not last long. Once it blooms it will self-seed. The flax plant is native to Europe.
column5: Blooms in summer.

column2: Periwinkle is perfect as a ground cover. The flowers resemble blue stars with a yellow center.
column3: Plant in full sun or partial shade.

column2: Petunia flowers feature sturdy easy to grow blooms that come in a variety of colors. They are annuals and grow from 6-12 inches on average.
column5: Blooms in early summer to mid-fall.

column2: Pincushion flowers are interestingly shaped. Scabiosa is one of the season’s longest blooming flower and they grow in blue/purple/white/pink.

column2: Polka dot plants (also known as Hypoestes phyllostachya) are a non-flowering plant. They are most frequently used as houseplants.

column2: Primrose (or Primula vulgaris) is a classic garden flower. There are hundreds of different varieties available and they are edible.
